question: Because you were a senior manager in big tech and I thought it would be really interesting for all the ICs out there to go over all of the PIP stuff that happens, all of the stack ranking behind the scenes, performance management, and of course I was curious about your career. So I guess before we dig into all that, maybe we can start with Amazon. Can you tell me a little bit about what you worked on and how you got to Amazon?

insights.insight: The author's early experience at Amazon involved working on a 'death march' project where they committed to delivering a product by October within their first week.
Amazon's culture of pushing engineers to work long hours and deliver results quickly can be both inspiring and demotivating, depending on individual perspectives and experiences.
The author's early career at Amazon was marked by a desire for technical depth, which they found lacking in their previous roles, and a willingness to adapt to a demanding work environment.

question: You went towards the advertising space. Was that something that you picked or was there was a general pipeline and you were placed somewhere?

insights.insight: Career choices can be influenced by external factors, such as recruiter specialization.
Opportunity and growth potential are important considerations when choosing a career path or team to join.

question: And so it looks like it turned out to be a huge grind. And I saw that you stayed there for some time, what was the average work like?

insights.insight: Long hours were common in big tech jobs, especially if one is ambitious and wants to achieve results.
Working hard and putting in extra effort is often required to get ahead in a demanding field like tech.

question: I saw that you grew through the early levels and then you also transitioned to management at Amazon as well. Are there any notable stories from your growth to an SDM (Software Development Manager)?

insights.insight: Being thrust into leadership roles without official title can be beneficial for personal growth, but may lead to premature promotion.
The transition to management is a common area where people struggle and make mistakes, but having the right support structure can help.
It's possible for individuals to feel overconfident in their abilities before gaining adequate experience and expertise as managers.

question: What were those early manager mistakes that make you say it was premature?

insights.insight: Management involves soft skills that are difficult to measure, making them easy to overlook.
Effective management requires understanding and knowing the goals and objectives of team members.
Lack of self-awareness and people skills can hinder a manager's ability to support their team effectively.

question: I see. You mentioned getting people to reveal their goals. Do you have any tips for that as a new manager?

insights.insight: Active listening is crucial for managers to gain insight into team members' goals and challenges.
New managers should be aware of the power dynamic shift and how it affects relationships with team members.
Engineers may struggle to open up due to their technical background, requiring managers to adapt their communication style.

question: You mentioned storytelling. For managers there's a lot of value in that. And I think also for ICs too, people talk about the storytelling behind talking about your work or maybe getting people interested in getting buy-in behind things. Do you have any tips on how to improve your storytelling?

insights.insight: Practicing self-awareness of one's own story is crucial in developing effective storytelling skills.
Recognizing the impact of a team's narrative on their performance and morale is key to effective leadership.
Critically evaluating one's own stories can help identify areas for improvement in communication and motivation.

question: You've mentioned your manager didn't have time for the niceties. What was your manager doing then, and how did you have that opportunity to kind of do that role before you even had that title?

insights.insight: Managerial priorities can be misaligned with traditional expectations, leading to unconventional delegation of responsibilities.
The tendency to focus on high-priority projects can lead to neglect of essential management tasks.

question: So then if you were to survey the sentiment of his org, do you think that people were unhappy with his behavior?

insights.insight: The leader's actions had a significant negative impact on the organization's morale.
Unaddressed leadership issues can lead to widespread dissatisfaction among team members.

question: Coming to the end of the Amazon leg, what was the thing that made you leave and want to join Meta?

insights.insight: The concept of 'good Amazonian' vs. 'good engineering leader' can lead to a sense of identity crisis in long-term employees.
Amazon's compensation and talent development model, while maintaining evenness, may make sacrifices in individual pay and growth opportunities.
Working on impactful projects with qualitative outcomes can be a key motivator for engineers looking to join companies that align with their values.

question: You mentioned Amazon's peculiar ways and how that might be different from what a good engineering leader is. What are those things that stick out to you where you thought, that's good for Amazon, but that may not actually be the thing that's for a good engineering leader.

insights.insight: There's no one-size-fits-all approach to leadership; different stages of company growth require different management styles.
Amazon's culture tends to prioritize efficiency and control, which can stifle creativity and innovation in later phases of a company's growth.
Effective leadership involves understanding the trade-offs between different management styles and adapting to the needs of the company at each stage of its growth.

question: You mentioned that at some point you transitioned to working on ML work and forecasting at Amazon, and I know you continue to work and Integrity is a very machine learning focused space. How was that transition for you? Was that challenging?

insights.insight: The transition to AI/ML requires not just knowledge of the field but also hands-on experience and experimentation.
Effective execution in AI/ML is as much about developing judgment and instinct through practice as it is about learning theoretical foundations.
Treating a transition to AI/ML as a mere study session can lead to a lack of practical skills and effectiveness in the field.

question: So you're saying the thing that helped you successfully transition was not necessarily learning those fundamentals, although you did it. It was the experience building the intuition behind what is improving model performance and building your own taste and intuition. Is that right?

insights.insight: Hands-on experience and practice are crucial for developing intuition in AI/ML.
Fundamental knowledge of AI/ML concepts is not as important as practical application for transitioning to the field.

question: Right. What was the motivation for moving into ML?

insights.insight: The guest was drawn to machine learning due to its unique ability to 'imply' a program from data, which was attractive and felt societally important.
The guest found machine learning applications beautiful in their complexity, particularly in how they combine multiple pieces to produce an output.

question: I guess, you know, going back to your time at Meta, I saw that you got promoted from a frontline manager to a senior manager, and I think a lot of people struggle with that growth. So I'm curious, you know, what did that look like for you? What was the story behind that promotion to M2?

insights.insight: The perception others have of you can be a significant headwind or tailwind in your career progression.
Leading other managers is significantly different and more challenging than leading engineers, requiring a deeper understanding of organizational dynamics.
It's essential to learn and adapt to new roles and responsibilities as you grow in your career, especially when transitioning from a frontline manager to a senior manager role.

question: The mutiny you mentioned is really interesting. How does that surface in practice? How, you know, how could someone underneath you kind of usurp you or kind of that mutiny could come in?

insights.insight: Managerial politics can arise through subtle, non-malicious actions by team members seeking to improve and grow.
Senior leaders must be aware of the potential for internal conflict and align individual goals with the organization's best interest.
Gamesmanship can occur in large organizations, even among well-intentioned individuals, which requires senior leaders to manage and mitigate these dynamics.

question: As a manager, especially not just a frontline manager, but more senior manager. Are you saying that there is a secret chess almost where there's a behind the scenes motives that people have, aside from the business motives that are maybe their personal career motives, that can lead to some unusual behaviors or maybe these political behaviors that you're talking about?

insights.insight: Senior leaders must consider the complex motivations of individuals within an organization, beyond just business objectives.
The presence of multiple, often conflicting goals among team members can lead to a 'secret chess' dynamic that affects behavior and decision-making.
To be effective, senior leaders must develop a catalog of common behaviors driven by these motivations and adapt their own actions accordingly.

question: It sounds like a lot of these behaviors are kind of zero sum behaviors. So I could imagine in an environment of either a shrinking company or stagnant company, or I guess sub-org of a company, that these would be more prevalent. And am I understanding correctly that if a company or an org is growing a lot, that's just abundance, so there's a lot less of this going on 'cause everyone can get what they want.

insights.insight: Leaders must focus on creating an environment where success is not zero-sum, but rather abundant.
Effective leadership styles change as organizations evolve, requiring more mature and attuned leaders in later stages of growth.
The imperative to win drives focus on performance, which is a fundamental aspect of successful leadership.

question: You mentioned when I asked about, what does mutiny look like? You said that, and I just want to confirm it was that M1 would go to your, their skip. So I guess your manager and say, Hey, Stefan is thrashing things. Are you sure he's good? Kind of things behind the scenes when in meetings you are not present.

insights.insight: As teams become more senior, leaders have less control over outcomes and must rely on binary decisions, such as letting underperforming managers go.
Senior leaders often struggle with delegating tasks to others, as they feel the need to personally intervene and 'do the job' themselves.
As teams move up the org chart, managers have fewer levers to pull in terms of turning things around and must rely on more drastic measures like letting people go.

question: You mentioned manager under performance. I'm curious because there were a lot of layoffs in the past. Do you feel managers have, they're harder to lay off than ICs are? And if so, why?

insights.insight: Managers' positions come with a larger 'blast radius', making them more impactful to remove from their roles.
Companies tend to target specific ratios of managers to ICs during layoffs, and often prioritize removing managers if they have too many reports or are not adding value.
Leadership positions come with significant responsibility and expectations, which can lead to higher salaries but also increased scrutiny and risk of being removed from their role during layoffs.

question: Yeah, I think I see the occasional comment that assumes that managers or, you know, leaders have some special treatment and they, you know, can't be fired or it's harder, but, yeah, I agree. I think we've seen that that is not necessarily the case that mentioned, types of leadership per stage of company, and they have, there's different effectiveness if the company's smaller or a more scrappy versus the larger companies. I'm kind of curious about that. What type of leadership do you think is most effective when the company's really small, and what type of leadership do you think is most effective when the company's very big?

insights.insight: Leadership styles change as a company scales from inspirational executors to organizational leaders.
Companies with different scaling strategies, such as Amazon and Meta, require different leadership approaches.
Large companies often suffer from entropy due to increased complexity, requiring leaders who can navigate this complexity.

question: When I asked you about the promotion to senior manager, you mentioned the size of your org and that managers were reporting to you. So it sounds like that was a big part of the promotion to have the scope to be a senior manager. I'm curious about the skill difference between an M1 and an M2 in your opinion. If we were to just imagine I took a random M1 or maybe yourself, and before you were promoted and you were just a new M1 and I, I put you in an M2 role and you just said have at it, what are the biggest skill gaps that you would've had?

insights.insight: Senior managers need to be able to add value to their reports, not just by giving them tasks, but also by considering the restrictions on how they can interact with their teams.

Small behavioral mistakes made by senior leaders can have a magnification effect and lead to significant problems, making it essential for M2s to develop good mental models of organizational dynamics.
There is an expectation that new managers will make mistakes when transitioning from IC to manager roles, but it's crucial for senior leaders to recognize and learn from these mistakes quickly.

question: You've experienced IC career growth and manager career growth. I'm curious to compare and contrast, you know, IC versus management, I guess growth paths. What do you think of the differences between the two? And also I'm curious, do you find that they're both meritocratic? I often hear that there's some, you know, cynical takes on some, you know, one being less meritocratic than the other. So, curious about your thoughts.

insights.insight: At high levels of leadership, it can be difficult to assess individual performance due to lack of clear evidence and transparency.
Meritocracy is challenging to achieve in management careers, as it's hard to tie individual contributions to specific deliverables at higher levels.
Unaccountability can be a issue in management careers, making it difficult for external observers to assess leadership effectiveness without time and hindsight.

question: I think one thing I was curious to dig into is that, you know, knowing that you've been at Meta and you've been at Amazon and you, you had a fair amount of time at both, I thought it'd be interesting to kinda ask you the pros and cons of each, or at least your personal experience. I know these companies are. Very large. And you know, some people have great experiences in a small team and others have bad ones within these companies. But I'm curious, when you think about Meta versus Amazon, what are the cultural differences that stand out to you?

insights.insight: Amazon is disciplined and has a strong focus on structured engineering design
Meta's culture values openness, collaboration, and empowering employees to make decisions
Amazon prioritizes process over people, while Meta prioritizes people over process
Access to data is a significant advantage for companies like Meta compared to Amazon

question: Having been a manager at each company, you experience the performance system intimately. What about comparing and contrasting the performance systems at Meta and Amazon?

insights.insight: Both Meta and Amazon have similar performance systems, with a public process for rating employees and a private process for investing in top performers.
The integrity of the performance review process is crucial to employee motivation and performance, even if it's just a 'ceremony' without tangible benefits behind the scenes.
Meta tends to invest more in top performers, while Amazon prioritizes fairness and frugality, which can impact the company's ability to attract and retain talent.

question: Yeah. I remember when I worked at Amazon briefly and one of the leadership principles was frugality and I, I never, I never liked that one, but, nobody does. Nobody does.

insights.insight: Frugality is a disliked principle among employees.
Leadership principles at Amazon may not align with employee values or preferences.

question: You know, with some of the layoffs that kind of happened in the past, there's mentions of lower low performer quotas, and I'm kind of curious, is that something that you experienced when you were working at these companies and how do they work?

insights.insight: Quotas for low performers are a necessary evil in large companies to maintain high performance, but can be uncomfortable for managers to enforce.
The gaming of performance reviews can lead to an inflated sense of achievement, causing companies to adopt lower performer quotas to correct this issue.
Managers' reluctance to let underperforming employees go often leads to a situation where the team starts to suffer, especially if it's not addressed promptly.

question: You mentioned PIPs. I'm curious, do you think that they work and you know, are there any differences between PIPs across the companies? This is based off that Reddit thread. I think someone asked, are they just a formality to create a paper trail? Or can people actually get out of a PIP?

insights.insight: PIPs need to have credibility and be fair to maintain their legal standing.
The effectiveness of a PIP is heavily influenced by the discretion of managers, who may have varying levels of motivation to support employees or follow HR guidelines.
Companies need to balance fairness and sensitivity when making terminations, prioritizing performance-based decisions and maintaining a reputation as a responsible employer.

question: With the rise of these AI cheating tools and, you know, LLM assistance. I'm curious, you know, how much do you see that coming up when you're either helping people prepare, or maybe you're just in the space, thinking about interview prep?

insights.insight: Companies may be weeding out cheaters through basic monitoring methods, but it's not a foolproof solution.
The future of software engineering and interviewing processes will need to adapt to the increasing use of AI tools.
Cheating in interviews may lead to short-term success, but it's unlikely to translate to long-term job performance, and can have negative consequences for both employees and companies.

question: I'm curious, 'cause I imagine an algo interview is more easy to cheat than a system design one. Do you see any differences in, I don't know, maybe the growth of algo interview signups is lower than the growth of system design signups or something that might make us infer that cheating has any impact on the future?

insights.insight: Companies are leaning more heavily into design interviews, particularly system and lower-level design, which requires reasoning about complex interactions between subsystems.
The quality of design in an AI-coded world is critical, and being able to reason through abstractions and come up with good designs is a valuable skill.
LeetCode still serves a purpose in the interviewing process, despite its flaws, as it caters to companies' needs for assessing candidates' coding skills.

question: If someone was hell bent on passing OpenAI or Anthropic interviews. What's the optimal game plan from your experience at Hello Interview?

insights.insight: OpenAI and Anthropic interviewers look for evidence of actual accomplishments, not just theoretical knowledge.
Preparation strategies should focus on understanding functional areas and being able to discuss technical accomplishments.

question: Coming to the end of the interview, I wanted to ask you some career reflections things. Just looking back on everything so far, kind of reflect on some of the things that you've learned. insights.insight: Job hopping can be beneficial for career growth in the early stages of one's career.
Moving around frequently at senior levels can be a sign of a lack of impact and effectiveness.
Finding a place to put down roots and make long-term changes is valuable for career advancement in senior positions.

question: Definitely. Yeah. And I think what you're saying about job hopping not being as effective later makes a lot of sense too, because, for instance, a lot of what you talked about in being a successful senior leader, either as an IC or as an EM, came through influence and credibility and your ability to get people to go in a certain direction. And that's one of those things that, I mean, if you just show up somewhere, you can build credibility. You can always rebuild credibility. But it is one of those things that, as you have, it's a snowball. It keeps getting bigger. Your credibility in that organization, you'll be able to move people a lot easier. So, you know, people who are early in their org. Have a disproportionate amount of influence because of their time in the role and what they've done already and what they know.

insights.insight: Early career success can lead to significant influence due to built-up credibility.
Credibility can become a double-edged sword, leading to both benefits and drawbacks, such as becoming 'stuck' in one's own reputation.

question: On the topic of writing. 'cause I know it's really important. I'm just curious, what would be your top tip? If there's some, you know, I see or em you're saying, Hey, you need to improve your writing. What would be the thing?

question: So if I'm understanding, it's to hone your taste as a reader first and that will let you critically reflect on your own writing and improve it.

insights.insight: Finding mentorship early on can save months of trial and error
Having a clear plan and agency to take action is key to growth and success
